For Night Owls, the Day Starts with a Nocturnal Morning

Read and listen to part three of ON MORNINGS, a nonfiction writing & podcast series

For some of us, the morning happens at night. Whether it’s from working the night shift or just being a night owl, these nocturnal mornings are more common than you might think. Truly, they’re not just for vampires.

A nocturnal morning can be a temporary affliction — a midnight inspiration, a late-night love affair. Or it can be the habit of countless days, a routine kept for months or years, working nights or fighting demons.

Here are seven true stories from people all over the world who experience a nocturnal morning. No two are the same. — From the Editor, Evyn Williams

I.

Babies choose to come at all hours. When I was newly pregnant myself and wracked by nausea and fatigue, I served as the midwife for a woman labouring at home with her fourth baby. As she laboured through the night, I used the breaks between contractions to gain control of my own discomfort. I would kneel down and press my burning cheek to the tiles of the bathroom floor, allowing the coolness to soothe my churning stomach and keep my heavy, tired eyes open.

At one point, the woman’s husband cracked open a window. With the in rushing winter air came the two-note call of a cardinal. A morning sound. Whether it was the air or the promise of the morning to come, I lifted my head, renewed. The woman bore down, and a lovely baby girl was born just before the sky could turn pink.

II.

Once you choose to be a journalist, you choose away traditional mornings. Stories very rarely happen within a nine-to-five frame. Most of them break at night.

When I first began thirty years ago, most of my nocturnal mornings kicked off with me holding on to a black bin bag, collecting half-empty trays of exotic takeaways left over from the evening meeting of the editorial team in a small radio station. There’s nothing like beginning your day surrounded by the smell of stale Vindaloo — or worse, Chinese prawns left next to the heated radiator — before you go on air to accompany cab drivers, health care professionals, and the odd funeral director through their night shifts.

Moving from radio to newspapers, I could find myself munching on dehydrated sausage rolls or cold pizza next to chain-smoking men in overalls and a bleary-eyed, not-quite-sober editor watching as paper was drawn into a massive, deafening printing press at three o’clock in the morning. Those were the good mornings — they meant I was woken up by a bellowing, short phone call informing me that my story had made the front page and I needed to show up.

Then there were countless emergency “morning” meetings, always happening at night. I’d throw on some clothes seconds after the call, phone a taxi, and be off. When I’d get to the office, I’d see that my jumper was inside out and that my jacket did not feel comfortable because I wore it upside down. If I was lucky, I’d have a matching pair of shoes on my feet.

It never fails to surprise me how different an office looks at four o’clock in the morning compared to four o’clock in the afternoon. The place contains the same furniture, the same equipment, and often the same people — but still is entirely foreign. Lack of noise is a major contributing factor to the alienation. People whisper in the nightly mornings as not to wake the non-existent neighbourhood; even the editor-in-chief will address the assembled workforce in a lower volume setting than his personality suggests. Very few traffic sounds seep through the windows and the simple act of moving a stapler or placing a cup on the table reverberates throughout the room — and within everybody’s minds.

The lights are also different. I hardly notice them during the day; at night, they hurt my eyes, my brain. They make me see that everybody in the room, including me, is just so much older, greyer, and worn than I remembered. Office lights at night make life unattractive — they reveal the ugly glory of all things.

The only factor that holds the ever-varying mornings together is coffee. Journalists will always be able to tell the newest fashion regarding the brew; machine brewed or cafetiere, instant or pods or shop-bought — nothing will start without coffee. Nobody will ever speak sensibly at four o’clock in the morning without a steaming cup in their hands.

Espresso, mocha, latte, and cappuccino I am sure were all invented because of journalists who staggered somewhere at an ungodly hour to cover a story that might or might not make the front page.

III.

My mornings are ruled by three things: dog, work, bar.

I have an old dog. And he has to go out in the real morning, but then I get to go back to sleep.

I don’t punch my morning timecard until 7 P.M. Not because I work in a factory, but because people are fickle. I freelance, and most of my work arrives at the end of the conventional day — the absolute last moment a client can commit. I’d love to throw a tantrum, but I always say yes.

The dive bar downstairs kicks off around 10 P.M. I like to pretend that The Moody Blues coming through the wall is actually a very important meeting happening in a nearby conference room. They too, like me, are working frantically. When a Lady Gaga anthem ballad comes on? I know we’re part of a larger community, all being furiously productive while the moon is high in the sky.

IV.

I’m unemployed. Sticking to a real schedule is harder now that I don’t have to wake up at a certain time, but I’m trying to get better about it. I promised myself I’d get to bed early tonight and wake up fresh at 9 A.M.

As I lie in bed, staring at the ceiling, I have an itch. It isn’t the type you can scratch; it’s the itch that almost flings you out of bed by force to do something.

I’m a writer. Not literature or anything, but the music type. And no matter how hard I try, I can’t help but feel the inspiration during the middle of the night. People make love at night; this is my version of that.

I get up and start working. By 1 A.M., my hands start to shake from the tedious task of aligning audio, adjusting volumes, adding percussion, arranging melodies. My wrist hurts. My neck is stiff from craning over the guitar sitting on my lap, reaching my arms over the keyboard, playing a 5 second bit over and over again, chasing perfection. My fingertips are callused and I’m still clearing my throat of the lingering phlegm left over from the cold I had nearly three weeks ago. Space bar, record, cough, spacebar, pause, ctrl-z, clear throat, spacebar, record, raspy sing into the microphone. I have to finish the vocals I started tonight; who knows if my voice will have the same amount of phlegmy-ness tomorrow.

I finish the song around 4 A.M. I am still itching, wanting to work on another, but I hold myself back. File, Save As. I turn off my studio monitors and feed the sound solely through my headphones as I click play and close my eyes. I hear my voice, the plucking of the guitar, the kick, the snare, the layered voicing, and I make mental notes. It’s not bad for a rough draft. I’m content with the night’s work.

I turn everything off and get back in bed. It’s still dark out, but there’s a rectangle of light that keeps my eyes from shutting. My phone floats above my head as I scroll through photo, after photo (like), after photo (like), after video (like), after ad (scroll faster), after video (laugh, then like). I give up and change the app, but the mechanics are the same. I scroll through the different messages people write, their lives cut out into little slivers.

The chirping is what I notice first. Then the small traces of light that start to peer through the shades of my window. I reluctantly lock my phone, throw it onto my bedside table, and toss my glasses next to it. I fall asleep thinking of the tweet I read about Pisces behavior and how scary-accurate it was, as if someone stalked me and wrote about my life specifically.

So much for 9 A.M.

V.

I can only sleep to noise.

Something about the night and the silence it carries is so absolutely calming and uncluttered. No one demanding anything of you. No one expecting anything of you. I am here and that’s exactly where I am supposed to be. I am never late for anything at night. The emptiness is full of possibilities. No traffic, no schedule, no angry chatter. Just silence.

So, I wait for the noise. The birds chirping, the coffee makers brewing, the cars starting. I wait for the noise so I can finally go to sleep.

VI.

It’s still sunny outside when I wake up at 7 P.M.

My hands head for the kettle first. The bubbly sound of pouring water fills my ears as my cup is filled. After the coffee is stirred and the spoon lands in the sink with a tinny noise, I’m on my way to the balcony.

I’m in my bathrobe, positioned comfortably on the balcony, legs leaning against the chair in front of me. I’m pretty high up, able to observe the evening street-goers while being barely seen. I’m holding the cup with both hands, letting its warmth linger on my fingers. I close my eyes and take a drink.

Bitter, welcome coffee drains down my throat. I think about everything and nothing.

I carefully put the cup on the tiles of balcony floor and reach for a pack of cigarettes I left here. The dry filter tingles in my mouth. I feel the consoling taste of unlit tobacco on my tongue while I look around for the lighter. After I find it, it takes a few tries before a small flame ignites, shaking and wiggling in the darkening air. I protect it with my hand and let the cigarette catch it.

The first puff of smoke fills my lungs. There is a particular joy to that first cigarette, post-slumber. I let the smoke drift out towards the bruise-blue sky. I close my eyes again and wait for the soothing combination of coffee and nicotine to spread through my body.

I hear the buzz of the traffic on the street below, people late for their dinners, the rush of heading home. I inhale, craving the serene tone of tobacco burning as the tip flares bright. I hear people out walking their dogs, coming back with groceries, going out for drinks. The night sounds nothing like the day; it’s electric, alive, but softer somehow, easier to get through.

My cigarette is barely lit in my hand. I dig it into the side of the ashtray, putting it out completely as dusk turns to deep night. There are no stars I can see.

I reach for my phone. The synthetic glow of the screen hits me as I browse through my social media. Friends on their way to pubs or clubs. It almost makes me numb now, to see what I’m missing. I scroll down, going back in time. Some complaints about work, a few jokes. The more I scroll, the closer to true morning I get. Lunch plans, pictures of food they ordered. Commuting to work.

I don’t belong to the world anymore, but the world didn’t stop.

VII.

My day starts as the sun sets. Blazing oranges and reds take over the horizon as the darkness and night stars chase the sun deep down into the earth. I’m the lone car on this stretch of the highway. Everyone else is in dead-stop traffic on the other side, their tail lights like a great digital snake blinking and winding its way to eternity in my rear view.

I enter the slowing city and looming buildings, the shadows growing long and street lights flickering to life. My coffee steams as the temperature drops. Black birds scatter and congregate as I push past them in the evening air. The wind whistles through the crack of my window.

Everyone is ready for sleep. I have never felt more awake.
